div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 1, 1890
div1.p:
To-day is Sunday. I did
not go to church this morning but took
a walk instead, I intend to go to
the different churches while I am here.

I walked across the Meadows which
are within half a block of where we
live and through the section of town
beyond them. It was a very lovely
walk. The houses are all built of
stone the style of architecture is varied
but the whole effect is harmonious.
Yesterday afternoon I walked over
to Holyrood Palace but for some
reason or other visitors were not
admitted, but I will have plenty
of time to visit it again.

The town is very hilly some parts
are connected with others by long
flights of stairs, and bridges connect
the high portions. This is only in
the old parts of town, the new
sections are graded.

I have not yet made a change in
my lodgings but I shall do so in
a few days. The habit of living in
a room to myself is too firmly fixed
on me, for me to take kindly to having
another person in such close quarters
And besides I think I can study
much better away from the
crowd. I g can get a students
lodging easily and live more
comfortably and for less money than
in the present arrangements.

And then I want to study the manners
of the people and I can do that
much better alone than when with
a party of my own countrymen.

I am sure I can make a great
deal out of the course at the University
here. I attend three lectures and
demonstrations every day and put in
the rest of the time in dissection and
study.

I hope my cablegram reached you
all right. I found that it would
cost the same to send it to Uncle
Tom as to you so I thought it
best to send to you.

It has not been raining yesterday
and today but it is cloudy at intervals
and always cold.

I got your very interesting and newsy
letter this morning and enjoyed it
very much. I did get your letter
written on the cars and I thought
I had mentioned it. I did not
get it until after I had written
my first letter and I must have
spoken of it in the letter I mailed
at Londonderry. I am sorry to
hear of Mr. Lazear's illness, the disease
seems to have a firm hold on him.

I am glad the trunk keys came all
right you must be careful not to
mislay the store-house receipt which
I sent with them as it might give
us some trouble to get them back.

It is raining again today. This is
a great place for rain but the
people don't seem to mind it. Nearly
all the men go about without
umbrellas, but as I am not a
native I stick to my umbrella.
The town is in a very exposed
situation and is not protected
at all from the wind from the
North Sea. The people all look healthy
however.

Mr. Magill our landlady's husband
called on us last night and he
was a great entertainment to us.
He is a typical Scotchman
with quite a broad accent, and
very strong orthodox Presbyterian
views. He considers that all the
trouble in Ireland is due to Popery.
In fact he seems to blame all
the ills of mankind on Popery.

He said that Glasgow was a terrible
place for business and he considered
the busy character of that city as
something very much against it.
He said he had to wait ten minutes
on a corner there before he could
across without being run over
and said that “they would'na allow
such a thing in Edinburgh”.

After talking for some time about the
doctrines of the Presbyterian Church, he
showed a very intimate knowledge of the
virtues of the various kinds of Scotch
whiskey.

Give my love to all at Uncle Toms and
Mrs. Millers
